bio.personalStatement:
My name is Mia and I am a software developer based in Newcastle Upon-Tyne. I work for Cambridge University Press and Assessment and I mainly work with Angular and .NET.

I studied at The University of Manchester where I completed an undergraduate degree in history, and then moved on to pursue an MSc in Computer Science at Newcastle University. I have since settled in Newcastle to develop my skills as a software developer.

I am very passionate about learning and continually improving my skills wherever I can. I am eager to learn new topics and have many random hobbies as a result. I speak Esperanto (as you can see from the translations on this webpage!), practice knife flipping, and do needle-felting.

I like to take any opportunity to find out something new and interesting and I hope to continue to further my career as a developer, alongside building my own projects in my spare time

Currently, I am working on my masters thesis, a project to create a database for international adoptees. During my undergraduate degree, I specialised in cultural history and I really enjoy merging my different interests together and using development for humanitarian purposes.

If you would like to find out more about my background, you can visit my LinkedIn, Github, or contact me directly at the below links.
Thank you for checking out my website!

projects.more: to view my Github profile. See below for some examples.
projects.please-click: For a deeper look into my coding projects, please click
projects.PDF-program: PDF Reading program. This program was created with Java to read PDFs, save progress, and skip to pages in an interface I can control. I read countless PDFs whilst studying history and was sick of the way they appear in your browser. I wanted to create a simpler way to read them without taking up a tab in my browser and with simple controls.
projects.esperanto-dictionary: Esperanto Dictionary. This is a simple Java dictionary program created to quickly lookup words in either Esperanto or English and find its translation. It works from a .txt file so more words can be added and changed at any time.
projects.pokemon-red: Pokémon Red. This command-line program was created with Python as part of the Code First Girls Intensive Introduction to Python course. The project recreates Pokémon Red as a fully interactive text based game.
projects.pokemon-database: Pokémon Database. This MySQL database was created as part of the Code First Girls Introduction to SQL. The project keeps track of each Pokémon's stats, abilities, evolutions, et cetera, all in a normalised form. It can be used to form Pokémon teams.
